explanation.text: The claim asserts that soluble copper significantly decreases the elastic modulus of the primary aluminum phase. This assertion is contradicted by experimental evidence from a reputable materials database.

The TotalMateria database explicitly states that copper raises the elastic modulus of aluminum from approximately 70 GPa (pure Al baseline) to 70-75 GPa in Al-Cu alloys, representing a 0-7% increase rather than the claimed decrease.

This finding is consistent with fundamental solid solution physics: copper has a much higher elastic modulus (≈130 GPa) than aluminum (≈70 GPa), so adding copper atoms to the aluminum matrix should increase the composite modulus, not decrease it.
The claim fails both directionally (predicts decrease but evidence shows increase) and quantitatively (requires ≥5% decrease for 'significantly' but observes 0-7% increase).

The score is -1 (Partially Infeasible) rather than -2 because while the claim is contradicted by available evidence for the Al-Cu system, it is not fundamentally impossible for some solute additions to reduce elastic modulus under specific conditions.

evidence_1.citation: Most alloying elements raise the modulus of elasticity of aluminum, but the increase is not substantial: for the aluminum-copper alloys the modulus of elasticity at room temperature is of the order of 70-75 GPa and practically the same in tension and in compression.

evidence_2.source: Materials science principles on solid solution strengthening and elastic properties
evidence_2.citation: Pure aluminum has an elastic modulus of approximately 69-70 GPa at room temperature. The elastic modulus of a solid solution typically increases or remains unchanged when a stiffer solute is added to a softer matrix.

evidence_3.citation: Many aluminum alloys have an elastic modulus of approximately 70 GPa (10 million psi).

evidence_4.citation: Copper has an elastic modulus of approximately 130 GPa, significantly higher than aluminum's 70 GPa. Adding a stiffer element to a matrix increases the composite modulus according to rule-of-mixtures approximations.

evidence_5.citation: Why not –2: Not fundamentally impossible for some solutes/conditions to reduce modulus; the claim is likely wrong as stated for Cu, but not a physics impossibility.
